title: Generic bit operations are cubersome

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-feature-request
labels.description: Category: A feature request, i.e: not implemented / a PR.

body:
I've tried to implement operations which operates on bitvectors. For example:

``` rust
fn set_bits<T, I = T>(start: I, end: I, val: T) -> T
    where T : ::core::num::Zero +
              ::core::num::One +
              ::core::cmp::Eq +
              ::core::ops::Not<Output = T> +
              ::core::ops::Sub<T, Output = T> +
              ::core::ops::Shl<I, Output = T> +
              ::core::ops::BitAnd<T, Output = T> +
              ::core::ops::BitOr<T, Output = T> +
              ::core::marker::Copy,
          I : ::core::num::One +
              ::core::ops::Add<I, Output = I> +
              ::core::ops::Sub<I, Output = I> +
              ::core::marker::Copy
{
    let len = end - start + I::one();
    let mask = (T::one() << len) - T::one();
    if !mask & val != T::zero() {
        panic!("Stored value is larger then field");
    }
    val << start
}
```

This has 2 problems:
- For relative simple operation it requires 13 trait declarations
- It panics for trivial edge case (setting all field)

The latter could be solved by using `Wrapping`. However for some reasons `Shl<usize>` is only `Shl` implemented for `Wrapping` while for all others `Shl<T>` is implemented (where `T` is the type). It would be nice if there was a `Bits<T, Index=I>` trait which would provide functions to operate on bits and `Wrapping` would use the same types as normal numerics.
